baseline_groups.claim_summary: Belief adjustments track Bayesian benchmarks but show asymmetric updating (stronger response to good vs bad news) that is attenuated by the Resolution treatment.
baseline_groups.notes: Six baseline specs correspond to Table 2 of the paper. They share the same outcome/treatment but differ by treatment-signal subsample. baseline = No-Resolution/Good Signal; baseline_nores_bad = No-Resolution/Bad Signal; baseline_nores_did and baseline_res_did pool both signals with signal and signal*bayes interaction; baseline_res_good and baseline_res_bad are Resolution subsamples. All represent facets of the same core claim about asymmetric belief updating.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Good news (positive signal) increases perceived importance of IQ for study performance in the No-Resolution treatment but not in the Resolution treatment (ex-post rationalization).
baseline_groups.notes: Table 3 results. The paper's claim is that signal has a positive effect on study performance ratings in No-Resolution (significant) but not Resolution (insignificant), as an ex-post rationalization mechanism.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Good news (positive signal) increases perceived importance of IQ for job performance in the No-Resolution treatment but not in the Resolution treatment (ex-post rationalization).
baseline_groups.notes: Table 3 results, job performance variant. Same logic as G2 but different outcome measure.

global_notes: The paper tests motivated beliefs via a lab experiment with 200 subjects. The primary hypothesis (G1) concerns asymmetric belief updating: subjects respond more to good news in No-Resolution but symmetrically in Resolution. The secondary hypotheses (G2, G3) concern ex-post rationalization of performance relevance. Some spec-search specs with outcome rang1-4posteriorbelief use rank-specific probability beliefs rather than the expected-rank summary measure (belief_adjustment) -- these are alternative measurements of the same underlying belief-updating concept. The heterogeneity splits (by age, IQ, prior, rank) run the same estimating equation on subsamples but are not separate baseline claims. The DID specifications (baseline_nores_did, baseline_res_did) pool good and bad signals with interaction terms, effectively nesting the separate good/bad signal regressions.
